description.narrative: The goal of the proposed programme is to mitigate the consequences of Covid-19 on the health system with provision of essential health commodities to ensure the continuation of essential health services delivery in 4 provinces of Zambia. The programme is intended to promote resilience of the health system as a mitigation for Covid-19 impact by ensuring essential health commodity security especially focused on vaccines, essential medicines and supplies for reproductive, maternal, newborn, child and adolescent health services. The aim is to serve an estimated 1 million people with primary health care services, 375 000 infants with routine vaccination services and 380 000 pregnant women with maternal health supplies. The programme will also procure and distribute personal protective equipment, oxygen concentrators and infection prevention supplies for 5 000 health workers to avoid Covid-19 infection and ensure a healthy and safe work environment. The supplies are estimated to serve patients for a period of 6 months but the programme duration will be 1,5 years to ensure consistent monitoring, oversight and follow-up as well as capacity-building. More specifically, the key results will be: - 375 000 infants and 380 000 pregnant women across the country received routine immunisation services with traditional vaccines (BCG, tetanus/diphteria, polio vaccine and measles/rubella). - 1 000 000 people accessing curative services including RMNCAH care in 983 primary health care facilities and 48 hospitals in 4 provinces for 3 months. - 5 000 health workers in 983 primary health care facilities and 48 hospitals are fully equipped with PPEs for 2 months. UPDATE The key results have been updated to reflect the additional 15 Million SEK from Sida. These are some of the key results with sligthly revised figures: - 375 000 infants and 380 000 pregnant women across the country received routine immunisation services with traditional vaccines (BCG, tetanus/diphteria, polio vaccine and measles/rubella). No change. - 1 000 000 people accessing curative services including RMNCAH care in 983 primary health care facilities and 48 hospitals in 4 provinces for 6 months. - 5 000 health workers in 983 primary health care facilities and 48 hospitals are fully equipped with PPEs for 4 months. - An estimated 4000 newborns receiving quality essential newborn care services at 5 hospitals in the 4 provinces and at UTH Lusaka. NEW - 22 health facilities equipped with cold chain equipment. NEW - Provincial Vaccines Store in Muchinga restored. NEW - 4 hospitals equipped with recommissioned oxygen plants to treat critical patients including covid-19. NEW - 5 hospitals equipped with neonatal supplies for quality essential newborn care services and 30 health workers trained. NEW
